body.input:
- legislate against discrimination in the workplace
- cover all stages of employment from pre-employment to end-employment decisions
- impose financial penalties and corrective directions on employers who breach obligations
- specify implementation timeline and milestones for the anti-discrimination law
- monitor situations of potential bullying of older workers regarding changes in employment status
- provide clarity on permissible questions related to protected characteristics during the hiring process
- discourage employers from asking questions about protected characteristics in hiring interviews
- collaborate with employers to adjust hiring practices and monitor compliance

- Maintain and promote access to property title and ownership information through the Integrated Land Information Service portal managed by the Singapore Land Authority.
- Ensure the Urban Redevelopment Authority's (URA) private residential property transactions e-Service provides timely data reflecting dynamic market trends for the real estate industry.
- Utilize caveats data and developer submissions to enhance the efficiency and accuracy of property transaction information.
- Complement existing e-Services with aggregated statistics to offer timely updates on market trends.

- require all new and existing buildings undergoing major A&A works to comply with the Code on Accessibility in the Built Environment
- mandate the provision of resting areas with seats along long paths of travel within buildings, with seating no greater than 50 metres apart
- design seats with armrests at an appropriate height to assist older persons or persons with disabilities
- publish Universal Design Guides to provide industry guidelines for accessibility features beyond mandatory requirements
- regularly review the Code to meet the changing needs of the population
- propose in the Draft Code on Accessibility in the Built Environment 2025 to require at least one passenger alighting and boarding point to be equipped with seats
- encourage public feedback on the Draft Code during the consultation period until 27 January 2025

- support the Workplace Fairness Bill to protect against workplace discrimination across 11 protected characteristics 
- emphasize the necessity of educating jobseekers about their rights and discouraging the disclosure of sensitive personal information during job applications 
- recommend that employers provide clear justifications for requiring specific characteristics in job advertisements to mitigate perceived discrimination 
- advocate for a stronger approach to reasonable accommodation processes for employees with disabilities 
- call for guidance and support for smaller organizations under the Workplace Fairness Bill 
- stress the importance of safeguarding the identity of complainants in the grievance resolution process 
- suggest that organizations develop effective internal processes to resolve issues related to workplace discrimination

- support the introduction of the Workplace Fairness legislation (WFL) to enhance workplace norms
- ensure workers are evaluated and hired based on abilities, free from discriminatory biases
- provide recourse for workers facing racial or religious discrimination at work
- allow employers flexibility in employment decisions based on genuine business needs
- afford religious groups some flexibility in making employment decisions
- promote fair employment practices and take an education-first approach towards compliance
- encourage a culture of trust and openness for raising and resolving workplace discrimination issues
- cultivate a shared understanding that everyone benefits from a fairer workplace
- engage tripartite partners in nurturing equitable workplace norms

- Track compliance with orders made by Small Claims Tribunals (SCT) and Employment Claims Tribunals (ECT) to identify sectors with higher non-compliance rates
- Ensure that persons who intentionally disobey court orders are subject to punitive actions under the Administration of Justice (Protection) Act 2016
- Implement enforcement measures against employers who fail to comply with ECT orders, such as warnings, fines, debarment from applying for work passes, and prosecution in court

- support the Workplace Fairness Bill to create fairer workplaces for all workers
- take a prudent and balanced approach to workplace fairness legislation to avoid disruptions to social harmony
- maintain employer-employee relations to prevent the workplace from becoming litigious and divided
- support the active advocacy for addressing age discrimination through age-friendly workplace practices
- promote greater education to reduce stigma around mental health and enact inclusive workplace practices
- implement guidelines for mental health support to ensure compliance and awareness among employers
- encourage provision of reasonable accommodations for Persons with Disabilities (PwDs) via an education-first approach
- focus on educating employers and employees about reasonable accommodations before mandating them through legislation
- support job redesign efforts to assist employers in providing accommodations for PwDs
- maintain that foreigners complement local workers to grow the economy while ensuring fair competition in the workplace
- continue investing in lifelong upskilling, reskilling, and career health initiatives for Singaporeans to secure better job opportunities
- enhance deterrence and penalties against discriminatory hiring practices through the Bill
- commit to revisiting and expanding the scope of the Bill in future to address additional forms of discrimination

- Provide assistance to Work Permit holders (WPHs) on issues related to dismissal
- Advise and assist WPHs in filing salary or wrongful dismissal claims
- Allow WPHs with valid salary claims to obtain another job while assisting investigations
- Regulate employment agency activities in Singapore to safeguard the interests of workers
- Set limits on recruitment fees charged by agents
- Engage with the industry to explore measures to reduce reliance on foreign recruiters for job placement
- Enforce obligations on employers to ensure prompt payment of salaries to WPHs

- target support at seniors with lower incomes during their working years who have little or no family support in retirement
- periodically review the Silver Support Scheme to ensure it targets those who need it the most and remains fiscally sustainable
- raise the qualifying per capita household income threshold for the Silver Support Scheme from $1,800 to $2,300 starting January 2025
- increase quarterly payments of the Silver Support Scheme by 20%
- periodically review and raise the Total Central Provident Fund Contribution threshold, which was doubled in 2021 from $70,000 to $140,000
- roll out additional measures to support all Singaporeans facing cost-of-living pressures, enhancing the Assurance Package to more than $10 billion
- include Budget 2024 Cost-of-Living Special Payment, Community Development Council vouchers, and additional U-Save and service charges rebates as part of cost-of-living support
- provide additional assistance through Comcare for seniors who need more help.

- Clarify the specific cases where the Government will use full NRIC numbers as an additional identifier.
- Provide details on when the Government will use other identifiers instead of NRIC numbers.
- Assure the public that in the majority of cases, the use of full NRIC numbers will not be necessary.

- safeguard food security and public health
- urge the Minister to address potential financial burdens on local farms due to new measures
- propose subsidies, grants, or technical support for farmers to comply with new regulations
- seek clarity on enforcement mechanisms for personal food import allowances
- suggest collaboration between SFA and e-commerce platforms to regulate transactions
- ensure that food safety regulations for donations do not discourage food donation efforts
- confirm safeguards to protect volunteers in food rescue initiatives from penalties
- advocate for consolidating food-related regulations under SOFA for clarity and efficiency
- prioritize affordability and accessibility in food security measures

- enhance passenger handling capacity at Changi Airport with the construction of Terminal 5
- strengthen Singapore's status as a leading air hub through improvements at Changi Airport

- Introduce new express feeder services as part of the Bus Connectivity Enhancement Programme
- Support express variants of trunk routes to improve public transportation efficiency
- support the use of MediSave for root canal treatment

- support the Insolvency, Restructuring and Dissolution Bill
- reduce the general eligibility criteria for SIP to a $2 million liability threshold
- protect creditors and employees affected by the inclusion of larger companies in SIP 
- strengthen safeguards against potential abuse of the Director's declaration of eligibility 
- retain the requirement to publish notifications in newspapers or ensure effective alternative notification methods 
- consider a compromise to extend the grace period for creditors from 30 to 60 days

- improve public transport networks to enhance overall attractiveness
- enhance recreation facilities to attract Malaysian travellers
- improve the overall shopping experience in the Marsiling, Woodgrove, and Woodlands areas
- engage other Ministries to work in a more comprehensive manner regarding merchant support

- enforce the ban on importation, supply, possession and use of e-vaporisers
- take stern actions against offenders involved in the illegal sales and use of etomidate
- support individuals seeking to stop the habit of vaping through the I Quit program by the Health Promotion Board
- recognize the harmful effects of vaping and reinforce commitment to the ban on e-vaporisers

- support affordable and reliable relief staff services for preschools
- establish a relief pool of manpower for preschools to address short-term staffing shortages

- enable Singaporeans aged 40 and above to attend longer-form industry-recognized courses through SkillsFuture Credit (Mid-Career)
- curate about 7,000 courses that provide better employment outcomes
- evaluate course effectiveness based on feedback from employers and course participants
- ensure that credentials obtained from courses are useful and relevant
- expand the list of courses in consultation with industry partners and sector agencies
- ensure that the findings of the review panel will be made public

- include measures to prohibit indirect discrimination against employees
- require employers to provide reasonable accommodations in the workplace for PwDs
- legislate the prohibition of indirect discrimination and denial of reasonable accommodation
- support initiatives that encourage collaboration between employers and disability organizations
- improve awareness and utilization of the Open Door Programme, Assistive Technology Fund, and the Accessibility Fund by employers

- educate the public about high-rise littering
- enforce penalties against high-rise littering offenders
- continue to deploy surveillance cameras to capture high-rise littering instances and support enforcement efforts
- utilize higher resolution cameras and longer deployment durations to improve detection rates of high-rise littering
- conduct educational outreach and stakeouts in areas affected by high-rise littering
- collaborate with Town Councils to deploy standees that indicate ongoing surveillance and display statistics on offenders
- explore new technological advancements for enhancing enforcement capabilities against high-rise littering, including the potential use of AI and drones
- strengthen partnerships with communities to develop localized solutions for addressing high-rise littering 
- urge residents to refrain from committing acts of high-rise littering as it threatens public safety and hygiene

- review licensing conditions for animal exhibitions to formalise requirements for reporting animal escapes
- ensure animal welfare and public safety are maintained during animal capture processes
- maintain a working arrangement for prompt reporting of animal escapes between NParks and Mandai Wildlife Group
- collaborate with Mandai Wildlife Group for coordinated responses in capturing escaped animals

- invest $1.5 billion over 10 years to develop and implement the Next Generation Electronic Medical Record (NGEMR) for the public healthcare sector.
- phase out more than 100 legacy information technology (IT) systems to reduce associated costs.
- improve coordination of care for patients by making detailed medical records and doctors' notes readily accessible across different public healthcare institutions.
- enhance workflow, raise efficiency, and improve health outcomes through the use of various analytical and operational IT tools within the NGEMR system.

- acknowledge that the Bill will not significantly reduce the total number of scams
- emphasize the necessity of a whole-of-society effort to combat scams
- work collaboratively with stakeholders to fight scams
- highlight the substantial financial losses from social engineering scams, specifically government impersonation scams, love scams, and investment scams
- advocate for public education as a crucial defense against socially-engineered scams

- Support P2P services as a complement to the public transport sector - Do not plan to cap the number of P2P platform operators - Ensure regulations for ride-hail services maintain an open and contestable P2P sector - Allow drivers to multi-home and not be tied to a particular operator - Promote increased competition in the P2P sector to drive innovation and service improvements - Ensure transparency of fares and commissions for operators to help drivers make informed decisions

- tackle high-rise littering
- intensify outreach and education efforts to instil socially responsible behaviour
- work with the community for ground intelligence on littering
- explore availability of higher resolution cameras and better surveillance technologies
- employ a multi-pronged and holistic approach to address littering
- cultivate more gracious behaviour and collective responsibility to keep Singapore clean and safe

- support Singaporeans in addressing cost of living issues
- support Singaporeans with daily expenses such as food and groceries
- boost the businesses of heartland merchants and hawkers
- allow arts-related businesses in the heartlands to apply to join the Community Development Council Vouchers Scheme on a case-by-case basis
- provide subsidised arts-related courses and programmes for residents in the heartlands

- Enforce action against suppliers engaging in unfair practices under the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act (CPFTA).
- Resolve cases through voluntary undertakings by suppliers to cease unfair practices.
- Obtain Court declarations and injunctions for severe cases of unfair practices.
- Address misleading and false representations under Section 4 of the CPFTA.

- support enhanced powers for Traffic Police to enforce traffic regulations against errant motorists
- oppose removal of mandatory minimum sentences and disqualification periods for careless or dangerous driving offences causing death or grievous hurt
- advocate for severe penalties to act as meaningful deterrence for dangerous driving behavior
- express concern over the proposal for defining repeat offenders based on speeding criteria
- urge reconsideration of the amendment regarding the definition of repeat offenders
no positions found
- TAFEP is effective in ensuring compliance among companies regarding employment guidelines.
- Engage the industry to harmonise and simplify banks' practices relating to post-death estate settlement and treatment of joint accounts.

- support the Food Safety and Security Bill
- strengthen and enforce the system for regulating food safety to protect public health
- require key food operators and farm feed suppliers to meet minimum stockpile requirements in addition to the existing requirements for white rice importers
- improve the level of procurement and production safety in the food industry
- increase the accountability of industry organisations in handling food, including record traceability and submission of food control plans
- address challenges faced by the food industry in adapting to the new food safety system, particularly for small companies

- improve connectivity at Keat Hong Close
- engage community stakeholders to review bus services under BCEP when new precincts are developed

- enable MOH to issue, administer and enforce food-related regulations for health promotion purposes
- support better population health and nutrition through the FSSB
- continue the current PHO ban under the new FSSB framework
- empower the Minister for Health to make food-related regulations for health promotion
- consolidate existing food regulations into the FSSB under Part 9
- require public consultation for new health promotion regulations
- appoint enforcement officers to ensure the compliance of food-related regulations
- strengthen preventive care measures to support healthier lifestyles

- support post-secondary education for students with special educational needs (SEN)  
- increase guidance and support for students with SEN in mainstream and Special Education (SPED) schools  
- implement Individual Transition Plans for SPED students to achieve post-school goals  
- encourage participation of students with SEN in internship programmes  
- provide pre-internship, employment workshops, and job matching programmes for students with SEN  
- promote self-advocacy among students with SEN in the workplace  
- partner with SG Enable for employment support for SPED students demonstrating potential for employment  
- enhance SPED Vocational Education curriculum to focus on soft skills and vocational guidance  
- allow eligible students in SPED schools to enroll in selected technical education programmes  
- provide incentives for employers to adopt inclusive practices for hiring students with disabilities  
- encourage employers to recognize the value of students with SEN in the workforce

- No compensation is warranted for personal information accessed, due to the public nature of information filed with ACRA.
- Information held by ACRA is intended to be publicly accessible as part of its registry function.

- extend time for users to file documents with Bizfile portal
- impose no late penalties for filing difficulties 
- provide assistance through ACRA personnel for those having difficulties with filing

- Require fish farmers exiting the industry to reinstate their sites to original conditions
- Mandate regulatory approvals prior to demolition by fish farmers
- Engage surveyors to perform sonar scans of the environment
- Assign account managers from the SFA to provide guidance to farms on the reinstatement process
- Conduct physical checks and investigate unauthorized dumping of marine debris by the SFA
- Implement enforcement actions against licensees found culpable, including liquidated damages and recovery of government costs for reinstatement

- address issues in the Malay/Muslim community through the Workplace Fairness Bill
- promote open conversations and discussions to address employee and employer needs
- ensure workers remain productive and are not impacted by workplace issues

- Increase the supply of COEs for Categories A and B every quarter until 2026 to meet growing demand from local buyers.
- Support the entry of new ride-hail service operators to enhance options for drivers and commuters in choosing their platforms based on preferences.

- Ensure availability of National Stadium (NST) for Singapore national football team during major tournaments
- Assess logistical feasibility for hosting multiple major events at NST
- Find alternative venue (Jalan Besar Stadium) for semi-final home match when scheduling conflicts arise
- Facilitate live broadcasts of football matches at community clubs and centres to engage more fans

- ensure sufficient Secondary 1 places to cater to all PSLE students
- guarantee a place in secondary school for every PSLE student who qualifies
- plan for larger PSLE cohorts in future years
- maintain comparative posting outcomes to previous years
- encourage students and parents to consider multiple school choices relative to previous year's COPs
- promote consideration of school culture and programs alongside student interests

- address the issue of drug use in vapes effectively
- work with agencies and partners to maintain safety in Singapore
- prevent complacency regarding drug issues

- rezone the land parcel at Amber Road from 'Reserve Site' to 'Residential' to meet housing demand
- minimize traffic impact from the development of the Amber Road land parcel
- ensure continued assessment of traffic situation when the land parcel is developed
- develop a new 0.5 hectare park along Tanjong Katong Road in the next few years

- Request clarification on the importance of clause 17(3) of the Bill for employers
- Suggest that examples demonstrating the significance of clause 17(3) be provided by the Minister during the round-up speech

- Reassure that discrimination in any form is not tolerated
- Define protected characteristics clearly in relation to the Bill (WFL)
- Outline five broad categories of protected characteristics
- Commit to reviewing and expanding the coverage of the Bill based on ongoing data collection and needs assessment

- Require employers to obtain workers' written consent before submitting Work Permit applications.
- Allow workers to approach MOM for assistance if they find an IPA has been obtained without their consent.
- Revoke IPA and conduct further investigations if an employer is unable to produce proof of consent.
- Prosecute employers who make false declarations on workers' consent when submitting Work Permit applications, carrying severe penalties including imprisonment.
- Continue to take feedback to review and improve processes related to Work Permit applications.

- clarify the policies surrounding the use of NRIC numbers in light of the introduction of PDPA
- reassure Singaporeans about the safety and precautions in handling NRIC numbers to prevent identity theft or scams
- establish actions to safeguard NRIC information and prevent misuse
- implement a timeline for organizations to rectify the use of NRIC numbers as default identification
- investigate why existing practices of using NRIC numbers as authenticators were not addressed earlier by the Government
- ensure fairness to civil servants, particularly ACRA, during the review process while recognizing shared responsibility in the matter

- increase the maximum operation of trains on the North East Line (NEL) from 36 to 42 trains
- monitor NEL ridership to adjust train frequencies accordingly
- ensure sufficient train capacity for commuters while maintaining safety and reliability of services

- Offer competitive salary packages to bus captains
- Improve working conditions and employment terms for bus captains
- Provide higher pay and more flexible work arrangements in the bus sector
- Offer attractive sign-on and retention bonuses for bus captains
- Enhance the welfare and working conditions of bus captains in collaboration with public bus operators and the National Transport Workers Union

- Expect overall passenger traffic to almost reach pre-pandemic levels in 2024 and further increase in 2025, likely exceeding pre-COVID-19 levels.
- Prepare for an increase in passenger volumes at Changi Airport before Terminal 5 is operational in the mid-2030s.
- Invest $3 billion over the next six years in Singapore Changi Airport Terminals 1 to 4 to improve services such as baggage handling, check-in, and immigration.
- View aviation as a growth sector that can provide many good jobs for Singaporeans.
- Undertake a sectorial manpower study with tripartite partners to attract, retain, and prepare workers for future growth in the aviation sector.
- Ensure that all equipment required for air navigation near runways is designed to break off in the event of a collision.

- Amend the Customs Act to improve the effectiveness of regulatory and enforcement operations by granting additional powers to Singapore Customs.
- Authorise auxiliary police officers (APOs) to exercise powers of search, arrest, and seizure under the Customs Act.
- Grant Singapore Customs legal power to require licensees to remove dutiable goods from licensed warehouses before license expiry or withdrawal.
- Provide customs officers the power to stop and conduct searches on belongings of individuals reasonably suspected of committing offences under the Customs Act.
- Allow Singapore Customs to seize devices and cash believed to be connected to offences under the Customs Act.
- Introduce a new offence for individuals allowing their premises or vehicles to be used for offences under the Customs Act, with penalties unless due care is shown.
- Introduce a new offence for altering, suppressing, concealing, or destroying records to obstruct Customs investigations.
- Enhance penalties for certain offences under the Customs Act, including increasing maximum fines for evasion of duties from $5,000 to $10,000 and allowing imprisonment terms in addition to fines for specified offences.

- establish procedures for creditors to enforce ECT and SCT orders
- allow individuals to set up new business entities without paying off prior debts
- maintain limited liability for shareholders of companies to foster entrepreneurship
- ensure proper distribution of company assets among creditors in accordance with insolvency law
- balance shareholder liability and creditor protection to promote a competitive economy and job creation

- Ensure Changi Airport operates smoothly and has the financial resources for necessary investments to build capacity and capability for the future.
- Support the increase in airport charges to facilitate ongoing investments for upgrading and maintaining Changi Airport's competitiveness.
- Advocate for continued evaluation of Changi Airport's performance and competitiveness, including connectivity, passenger experience, and service levels.
- Emphasize that the increase in airport charges will allow for wage growth for airport workers in line with national initiatives, such as the Progressive Wage Model, and improve working conditions for airport staff.

- support bus connectivity enhancement in areas further away from town centres and MRT stations
- increase bus services in tandem with estate growth
- provide direct connections to amenities and schools through bus services
- continue to engage community stakeholders in reviewing bus services under the BCEP

- legislate age limits for social media access to protect children and youths
- study the effectiveness of mandating age limits
- engage with Australian counterparts on social media platforms to inform decision-making
- implement Code of Practice for Online Safety in 2023 requiring social media services to enhance user safety
- ensure children are not targeted for detrimental content
- require implementation of age assurance methods to minimize children’s access to harmful online content
- establish Code of Practice for Online Safety for App Distribution Services to ensure age-appropriate app access
- step up public education efforts on online safety through Cyber Wellness lessons in the MOE's CCE curriculum
- launch Parenting for Wellness by MOE, MSF, and HPB in 2024
- provide Online Safety Digital Resource Kit on the IMDA's DfL portal
- collaborate with industry and community partners for online safety initiatives

- confer authoritative status on the electronic Gazette
- ensure electronic Gazette is treated as prima facie evidence of its contents
- allow electronic Gazette to prevail over all other versions in case of inconsistency
- require courts to take judicial notice of electronic Gazette in addition to print version
- allow electronic versions of revised legislation to prevail over print versions
- abolish the use of the Gazette as an instrument of statutory appointment

- harness the expertise of MOH, HPB, and NCID to improve public health cooperation
- create an ecosystem for public health practitioners to share knowledge and solve problems
- strengthen capabilities for communicable disease prevention, control, and response
- support professional growth and career progression for CDA officers
- provide structured learning opportunities for CDA officers
- ensure alignment of CDA's work with national policies
- collaborate with agencies like NEA, Singapore Food Agency, and National Parks Board to address public health issues
- adopt a multi-agency cooperation framework termed "One Health"
- strengthen communication and coordination for public health and disease response
- engage internationally with organizations like WHO to advance public health interests
- participate in international scientific and surveillance networks for disease information sharing
- focus on communicable diseases while coordinating with other ministries for disaster management issues

- enhance competitiveness for businesses across Singapore
- implement heartland place-making grants for heartland enterprises
- continue neighbourhood upgrading plans nationwide
- provide Community Development Council vouchers to supplement residents' spending and support businesses in the heartlands

- support provisions on mental health in the Workplace Fairness Bill
- recognize mental health conditions as a protected characteristic
- prohibit employers from making adverse decisions based on an employee’s mental health status
- establish grievance processes for reporting discrimination without fear of retaliation
- ensure clear diagnostic criteria for mental health conditions to qualify as protected
- balance workplace safety and fairness for employees with mental health conditions
- establish unbiased and transparent grievance handling processes
- implement robust privacy and confidentiality safeguards for mental health information
- promote mental health as a national priority through community programmes and awareness campaigns

- Evaluate the effectiveness of courses eligible for SkillsFuture Level-Up Credit in addressing the unique learning needs of mid-career working adults.
- Review programmes to ensure they deliver maximum impact and relevance over time.
- Ensure that credentials accredited or awarded under the SkillsFuture programme are both industry recognised and valued by employers.
- Assess tangible improvements in employability and job performance for participants of the SkillsFuture programme.

- decrease in the number of motorists making illegal U-turns from 7,700 in 2019 to 2,000 in 2023 indicates effective enforcement measures are working
- Traffic Police should track the number of injuries and deaths caused by traffic law violations

- Address public misconceptions and stigma surrounding mental health through mental health literacy.
- Raise awareness about mental health conditions via campaigns like HPB's "Supporters who Listen, Support Better" and NCSS's "Beyond the Label".
- Provide educational resources on platforms such as Mindline.sg.
- Conduct public education and outreach efforts by AIC and HPB to recognize and support individuals with mental health conditions.
- Offer community-level support for vulnerable groups through initiatives like Well-being Circles, Community Outreach Teams, and Community Intervention Teams.
- Targeted outreach for seniors through Silver Generation Ambassadors and CareLine, a 24/7 social support hotline.
- Strengthen ongoing efforts as part of the National Mental Health and Well-being Strategy to address stigma, especially in specific populations.

- ensure access to a good range of food options for students
- explore different canteen operating models, including central kitchens
- preserve the livelihoods of existing stallholders who want to work
- require central kitchen operators to serve meals adhering to HPB's guidelines for a balanced diet
- implement easier quality checks for food prepared in central kitchens by HPB officers
- work closely with central kitchen operators to gather feedback on meals from parents and students
- explore a variety of canteen models to complement individual stallholders for nutritious and affordable food

- ensure a thorough and fair review process for ACRA and MDDI
- refer matters to relevant authorities if actionable wrongdoing or serious lapses are uncovered

- There was communication between ACRA and MDDI concerning concerns raised by ACRA.
- A clear understanding of policy intent was lacking in communications between ACRA and MDDI.
- There was a lapse of coordination noted in the interactions between ACRA and MDDI.
- The decision to release or not release the document should be left to the review panel to decide.
- The most relevant part of the circular minute is the instruction to "cease the use of partial, masked NRIC numbers."

- Establish obligations and responsibilities for food-related businesses to ensure food safety and resilience.
- Require vending machine operators to display cleaning dates and sell-by dates for perishable foods.
- Advocate for food businesses to implement food control plans for safety and hygiene, including tailored training for staff.
- Ensure that new food business owners are educated on compliance with safety requirements.
- Consider past employment contraventions in assessing the suitability of food business license applicants, especially in sectors under the progressive wage model.
- Support the Bill as a means to enhance food safety culture in Singapore.

- support the Bill that codifies protections against discrimination in the workplace
- support clause 8(a)(i), which includes "language ability" as a protected characteristic
- call for the inclusion of gender identity and sexual orientation as protected characteristics in the definition of 'sex'
- express concern over implications of clause 10(2) excluding sexual orientation and gender identity from protections
- request clarification on the intention behind explanatory note on clause 17
- advocate for stronger protections against discrimination on the basis of gender identity and sexuality in the workplace
- encourage the Minister to ensure that reporting systems for workplace discrimination are accessible and trusted for LGBTQ+ individuals
- propose collaboration with LGBTQ+ groups for training on handling discrimination cases
- suggest that the law should be re-examined in the future regarding the exclusions at clause 10(2)

- foster interest in knowledge and learning acquisition in early formal schooling levels
- address the high stakes testing culture in education that promotes studying solely for tests

- provide additional support for lower-to-middle income first-time households buying new or resale flats through the Enhanced CPF Housing Grant (EHG)  
- increase the maximum EHG to $120,000 for families and $60,000 for singles, with higher increases for lower-income households  
- disburse the EHG before eligible buyers sign the Agreement for Lease for BTO flats, allowing use of EHG for downpayment  
- report on the increase in EHG disbursement for resale applications registered following the EHG enhancement

- fund research studies to understand the needs of senior citizens
- support senior citizens to age well in the community
- identify vulnerable seniors and connect them with relevant support services
- provide active ageing programmes and befriending services through Active Ageing Centres
- track the number of vulnerable seniors referred to and supported by community services

- work with professional bodies, trade associations, and business associations to enhance legal counsel awareness
- collaborate with insolvency professionals to promote restructuring advice
- refine and enhance SIP 2.0 based on feedback from relevant MSCs and business communities

- maintain and upkeep community facilities at Petal Gardens
- ensure accessibility of facilities at Petal Gardens for residents
- complete cyclical maintenance and improvement works by Q1 2026
- ensure continued availability and accessibility of community activities for all Eunos residents

- communicate legal assistance services more effectively to residents
- resource SSOs and Community Clubs better for legal aid support
- address the challenge of residents not being digital savvy or proficient in English regarding legal services
- seek clarification on the inclusion of gender equality in legislation

- ensure migrant workers have access to food in dormitories
- promote cooking and purchasing options for meals among migrant workers
- educate migrant workers on good nutrition through distribution of educational materials
- require employers that cater food to use licensed food caterers
- encourage employers to provide more nutritious food for migrant workers
- provide a channel for migrant workers to report food-related issues through FWMOMCare mobile application
- commit to constantly review and improve the legislative framework related to the Bill

- Ensure quick issuance of ROs to block suspicious transactions to protect potential victims from scams.
- Address the potential scale of scam incidents by improving systems for handling multiple cases simultaneously.
- Introduce public education initiatives to make Singaporeans aware of scams and enable them to protect themselves.
- Create support networks, such as grassroots organisations, to assist seniors with the appeals process under the Bill.
- Ensure the appeals process is fair and offers personal hearings for complex cases rather than relying solely on documents.
- Implement regular reviews and publish anonymised outcomes to enhance transparency and build trust in the appeals process.
- Work with banks to provide clear guidelines, training, and support to prevent scams without overwhelming them.
- Propose the establishment of a regional task force and a global registry for scam accounts to combat international scams.
- Prioritise robust training and resources for bank employees and AI systems to minimise errors in account restrictions.
- Establish neutral support systems, such as community networks and counselors, to assist scam victims.
- Tackle underlying vulnerabilities such as loneliness and financial insecurity that scammers exploit to protect the community.

- Raise concerns about the potential downsides of discontinuing the use of masked NRIC numbers.
- Question the necessity of eliminating the practice of masked NRIC numbers if the public is comfortable with it as a middle-ground solution.

- support continuous upskilling and reskilling in education
- implement programmes that promote 'the joy of learning'
- adopt the phrase 'learn more, test less' in the education system
- focus on learning for life rather than solely for exams
- encourage a desire for learning beyond just test preparation

- provide a one-off SkillsFuture Credit top-up of $500 for eligible Singaporeans
- encourage individuals to utilize the $500 top-up meaningfully
- offer a wide range of around 30,000 skills-related courses
- enhance the mySkillsFuture portal to improve course search functionality
- publish jobs and skills insights to guide training decisions
- offer free Skills and Training Advisory services for personalized guidance
- welcome community partners to raise awareness of SkillsFuture Credit and eligible courses

- Ensure that telemedicine practices provide appropriate clinical care.
- Investigate the adequacy of teleconsultation practices in terms of time and information provided.
- Assess the necessity of inpatient consultations depending on the situation.

- conduct a review of the postal firm as a whole to ensure proper management and adequate processes are in place. - provide assurance regarding the representations made by the firm about its domestic obligations and operations.

- address the atrophy of adaptive skills in the workforce
- ensure continuous learning opportunities for the workforce, particularly for those aged 35 and above
- collaborate with employers and stakeholders to curate development programs that fit within work responsibilities
- rethink the approach to learning beyond traditional courses to enhance the effectiveness of skill application

- support the Protection from Scams Bill as an important step towards combating scams
- advocate for systemic safeguards to prevent scams before they occur
- propose that financial institutions, telecommunications companies, social media companies and messaging providers be held accountable for preventing scams on their platforms
- call for the establishment of an independent investigative body to handle scam-related cases concerning banks' adherence to their obligations under the Shared Responsibility Framework (SRF)
- suggest that banks must collaborate with digital wallet providers to implement real-time fraud detection algorithms for monitoring all digital wallet transactions
- emphasize the need for financial institutions to enhance back-end fraud detection by incorporating account data, behavioural analysis, and anomaly detection
- recommend the creation of a centralised scam database to consolidate scam reports and share information across platforms
- propose that the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) assess and rate the anti-scam measures of financial institutions and platforms

- Support legislation that covers individuals of different sexual orientations and gender identities (SOGI).
- Advocate for the fair treatment of LGBTQ individuals in the workplace.
